title: SEC’s Advisor Rules Face Long Battle
text:
Text size

The SEC’s investment advice reform package faces an extended legal battle that is unlikely to be resolved before the new regulations must be implemented next year, writes InvestmentNews.

“Although the outcome is impossible to predict, it will hinge on whether a court decides the SEC ignored a congressional mandate to set a uniform fiduciary standard for all financial advisers or acted within its authority to create a new broker requirement separate from the investment adviser standard,” writes InvestmentNews.

One suit filed last week by seven state attorneys general argues that the SEC violated the Administrative Procedure Act by promulgating a broker requirement — Regulation Best Interest or Reg BI — that doesn’t follow lawmakers’ direction in the Dodd-Frank financial reform law. It calls for formulating a uniform standard of conduct that is no less stringent than the fiduciary duty that currently applies to registered advisors.

The attorneys general say Reg BI won’t adequately protect investors from conflicted advice. They also assert that states will lose tax revenue as a result of the lower value of retirement distributions and will have to take on the costs of caring for retirees who don’t have enough savings.

“This is not just about the Administrative Procedure Act; it’s also about federalism,” said Marlon Paz, a partner at Mayer Brown, told InvestmentNews. “It’s about the states’ ability to protect their citizens and the federal government’s ability to dictate a national [advice] standard. There’s a long road ahead.”

A separate suit filed by XY Planning Network also argues that the SEC sidestepped Dodd-Frank. In addition, it claims Reg BI puts investment advisOrs at a competitive disadvantage because “it makes it more difficult to differentiate their fiduciary standard of conduct from the lower standard of conduct now applicable to broker-dealers.”

-- John Kimelman
description: Courts will decide whether the SEC ignored a Congressional mandate to create uniform rules for brokers and advisors.
